mNAROx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Need large areas within their home ranges that are generally isolated from human activity.  Density was estimated at one otter per 86 ha of coastal marsh in Louisiana (Shirley et al. 1988, in NatureServe). ****Utilize NWI layer wet vegetation, if necessary.  Dependent on how model looks Alternative- may be able to select all pixels that are within 60m of rivers and streams (forested) in addition to all wetland classes. Amy Silvano 27june05

references.A06GOR02USGP: Gorman, T.A., J.D. Erb, B.R. McMillan, D.J. Martin, and J.A. Homyack. 2006. Site characteristics of River Otter (Lontra canadensis) natal dens in Minnesota. American Midland Naturalist 156: 109-117.
references.A88SHI01NAUS: Shirley, M. G., et al. 1988. Population estimates of river otters in a Louisiana coastal marshland. J. Wildl. Manage. 52:512-515.
references.A01RAE01USGP: Raesly, E.J. 2001. Progress and status of river otter reintroduction projects in the United States. Wildlife Society Bulletin 29:856-862.
references.A07JOH01USGP: Johnson, S.A., H.D. Walker, C.M. Hudson, T.R. Hewitt, and J.S. Thompson. 2007. Prospects for restoring river otters in Indiana. Proceedings of the Indiana Academy of Science 116(1):71-83.
references.NOCODE512: Lariviere, S. and L.R. Walton. 1998. Lontra canadensis. Mammalian Species No. 587. Am. Soc. Mammal., New York.
references.B77LAY03SEGP: Layne, J.N.; Stallcup, J.A.; Woolfenden, G.E.; McCauley, M.N.; Worley, D.J.  1977. Fish and Wildlife Inventory of the Seven-County Region Included in the Central Florida Phosphate Industry Area-Wide Environmental Impact Study. Volumes I and II.  Also available as PB-278 457, Price codes: A99 in paper copy, A01 in microfiche. September 1977. Volume I - 643 p, 123 fig, 34 tab, Volume II - 635 p, 164 fig, 7 tab.
references.A06GOR01USGP: Gorman, T.A., J.D. Erb, B.R. McMillan, and D.J. Martin. 2006. Space use and sociality of River Otters (Lontra canadensis) in Minnesota. Journal of Mammalogy 87: 740-747.
references.R03MEC01USGP: Mech, L. David.  2003.  Incidence of Mink, Mustela vison, and River Otter, Lutra canadensis, in a highly urbanized area.  Canadian Field Naturalist 117(1):115-116.  Jamestown, ND: Northern Prairie Wildlife Research Center Online.  http://www.npwrc.usgs.gov/resource/mammals/minkottr/index.htm
references.A09GAL01USGP: Gallant, D., L. Vasseu, M. Dumond, E. Tremblay, and C.H. Berube. 2009. Habitat selection by river otters (Lontra canadensis) under contrasting land-use regimes. Canadian Journal of Zoology 87:422-432.
references.A06BOY01USGP: Boyle, Steve. 2006. North American river otter (Lontra canadensis): A technical conservation assessment. USDA Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Region. Available: http://www.fs.fed.us/r2/projects/scp/assessments/northamericanriverotter.pdf
references.A90DUB01USGP: Dubuc, L.J., W.B. Krohn, and R.B. Owen, Jr. 1990. Predicting occurrence of river otters by habitat on Mount Desert Island, Maine. The Journal of Wildlife Management 54:594-599.
references.B98WHI01NCGP: Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.
references.B97BRO01NAUS: Brown, L. N. 1997. A guide to the mammals of the southeastern United States. University of Tennessee Press, Knoxville. xiv + 236 pp.
references.A51LIE01USGP: Liers, E.E. 1951. Notes on the river otter (Lutra canadensis). Journal of Mammalogy 32: 1-9.
references.U75LOW01NAUS: Lowman, G. E. 1975. A survey of endangered, threatened, rare, status-undetermined, peripheral, unique mammals of thes.e. National Forests and Grasslands. USDA Forest Service Contract 38-2601. 121 pp.
